message.content:
We start by computing each ratio using the figures provided in the balance sheet, cash flow statement, and income statement.

Step 1. Debt to Asset Ratio

• First, determine the total liabilities. In this problem the liabilities come from the balance sheet items “Accounts Payable” and “Taxes Payable”. (Note that Total Liabilities = Total Assets – Total Owner’s Equity.)
  Total Assets (end) = 14,879,933.86  
  Total Owner’s Equity (end) = 11,824,937.81  
  Total Liabilities = 14,879,933.86 – 11,824,937.81 = 3,054,996.05

• Now, compute the Debt to Asset Ratio:
  Debt to Asset Ratio = Total Liabilities ÷ Total Assets  
  = 3,054,996.05 ÷ 14,879,933.86 ≈ 0.2053  
Rounding to two decimal places gives ≈ 0.21

Step 2. Operating Cash Flow to Net Income Ratio

• Using the cash flow statement:
  Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities = –5,394,333.52  
  And from the income statement, Net Profit = –1,175,062.19

• Since both values are negative, their ratio is positive:
  Operating Cash Flow to Net Income Ratio = (–5,394,333.52) ÷ (–1,175,062.19)  
  = 5,394,333.52 ÷ 1,175,062.19 ≈ 4.59

Thus, the final answers are:

{
  "solution": {
    "Debt to Asset Ratio": "0.21",
    "Operating Cash Flow to Net Income Ratio": "4.59"
  }
}
